prior_works.title: Nonclairvoyant Scheduling
prior_works.authors: Rajeev Motwani, Cynthia Phillips, Erik Torng
prior_works.role: Foundational model and baselines for non-clairvoyant flow-time scheduling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper builds directly on the classic non-clairvoyant setting defined by Motwani–Phillips–Torng (e.g., SETF/Round-Robin without job sizes), extending the feedback model from zero information to continuous progress signals and analyzing competitiveness in that richer, still non-clairvoyant, regime.

prior_works.title: The Geometry of Scheduling
prior_works.role: Core analytic toolkit for flow-time scheduling (dual fitting, resource augmentation)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The competitive analyses for progress-bar–driven algorithms leverage the dual-fitting/resource-augmentation perspective popularized by Bansal–Pruhs, adapting these techniques to handle dynamic, potentially adversarial progress feedback.

prior_works.title: Competitive Caching with Machine Learned Advice
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s improved guarantees for learning-augmented scheduling and its adversarial-progress results are framed in the consistency/robustness paradigm introduced by Lykouris–Vassilvitskii, showing how continuous feedback can tighten bounds relative to one-shot predictions.

prior_works.title: Improving Online Algorithms Using ML Predictions
prior_works.authors: Manish Purohit, Zoya Svitkina, Ravi Kumar
prior_works.role: Blueprints for incorporating predictions into online decisions and blending with robust baselines
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The progress-bar model generalizes one-shot predictions studied by Purohit–Svitkina–Kumar; the paper adapts their prediction-aware vs. worst-case tradeoff ideas to continuous, possibly noisy, signals and shows how to retain robustness while exploiting feedback.

prior_works.title: Online Scheduling with Predictions (Price of Misprediction)
prior_works.authors: Silvio Lattanzi, Christopher Lavastida, Benjamin Moseley, Sergei Vassilvitskii
prior_works.role: Learning-augmented flow-time scheduling with job-size predictions and error-sensitive guarantees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing that adversarial progress bars imply stronger bounds than those known for size-prediction models, the paper directly refines and extends the guarantees of Lattanzi–Lavastida–Moseley–Vassilvitskii to a richer signal model.

prior_works.title: Online Makespan Minimization with Machine Learning Predictions
prior_works.authors: Sungjin Im, Benjamin Moseley, Karthik Purohit, Ola Svensson
prior_works.role: Techniques and meta-principles for robust scheduling with predictions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s general method for combining scheduling algorithms echoes prediction-aware/robust meta-designs from Im–Moseley–Purohit–Svensson, extending the meta-combination idea from makespan to flow-time under continuous progress feedback.

prior_works.title: A proof of the optimality of the shortest remaining processing time discipline
prior_works.role: Clairvoyant gold standard for minimizing total flow time (SRPT)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SRPT is the clairvoyant benchmark; the stochastic progress-bar model recovers SRPT-like behavior as signals approach true remaining work, and the paper’s asymptotic optimality results are calibrated against this classical optimum.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper positions itself at the intersection of classical non-clairvoyant flow-time scheduling and learning-augmented online algorithms. It roots its model in the seminal non-clairvoyant framework of Motwani–Phillips–Torng, but augments the information structure: instead of no size information, the scheduler receives evolving progress signals. To analyze such algorithms, the work draws on the dual-fitting and resource augmentation toolkit of Bansal–Pruhs, tailoring these methods to accommodate time-varying, potentially adversarial progress bars.

On the learning-augmented side, the paper explicitly inherits the consistency/robustness goals introduced by Lykouris–Vassilvitskii and operationalized across problems by Purohit–Svitkina–Kumar. Prior scheduling-with-predictions results (e.g., Lattanzi–Lavastida–Moseley–Vassilvitskii) provide baselines and error-dependent guarantees for job-size predictions; the authors show that adversarial progress bars strictly strengthen these guarantees, effectively subsuming one-shot size predictions. Their "algorithm-combining" method mirrors meta-designs from prediction-aware scheduling (e.g., Im–Moseley–Purohit–Svensson), but generalizes them to blend multiple flow-time algorithms under continuous feedback while preserving worst-case safety.

Finally, the stochastic progress-bar model connects to classical clairvoyant optimality: as signals become more informative, policies gravitate toward SRPT (Schrage), and the authors prove asymptotic optimality against this gold standard. Collectively, these prior works shape the paper’s core innovation: elevating non-clairvoyant scheduling from static ignorance or single-shot predictions to continuous, analyzable feedback—yielding stronger adversarial guarantees, principled algorithm combination, and stochastic optimality.
